of Molecular Catalysis, 62 (1990) 147-156 147 CHIRAL RUTHENIUM CATALYSTS FOR ASYMMETRIC HYDROGEN TRANSFER REDUCTION OF ACETOPHENONE: ORIGINAL EFFECT OF ASBESTOS ON ENANTIOSELECTIVITY REMI CHAUVIN Laboratoire de Synthese Asymetrique, University Paris Sud, 91400 Orsay (France) (Received January 15,1990; accepted March 30,1990) Summary The preparation of new chiral ruthenium complexes of (+ )-diphenyl- phosphinite pantolactone and (+)-diop is reported. Their catalytic properties in asymmetric hydrogen transfer from 2-propanol to acetophen- one are investigated. In the framework of this reaction, the ability of asbestos to influence the kinetics, yield and enantioselectivity of asymmetric catalysis is evidenced. Using the complex [Ru(OAc)2((+)-diop)]n, the overall optical yield changes from 12% in (+)-alcohol in the absence of asbestos, to 19% in (-)-alcohol in the presence of asbestos. Kinetic studies emphasize the determining influence of the activation conditions, the one-electron ligand of the ruthenium complex, and the ratio g[asbestos]/mol [Ru]. Introduction In contrast with some chiral amine-iridium complexes [I], chiral phosphine [2] or phosphinite [3] rhodium and iridium complexes have provided moderately enantioselective catalysts for hydrogen transfer from alcohols to ketones. Achiral phosphine ruthenium complexes give poorer catalysts [4], but the enantioselectivity of analogous chiral complexes has not been examined to our knowledge. Although phosphine-ruthenium complexes were used as hydrogenation catalysts, before Wilkinson's discovery of his rhodium catalyst [5], only recently has interest arisen to use this cheaper metal in catalytic reduction reactions. Binap ruthenium complexes were found to catalyze the asymmetric hydrogenation of various alkenes [6,7] and functional ketones [8] under high pressure with very high enan- tioselectivities. However, acetophenone is not hydrogenated by such com- plexes; since it is readily reduced by hydrogen transfer, we sought to investigate the hydrogen transfer reduction of acetophenone catalyzed by ruthenium complexes with chiral phosphorus ligands. The complex 2 contains two phosphinite ligands per ruthenium atom (they were not destroyed in the basic and high temperature conditions required to obtain a homogeneous solution). In contrast to other complexes synthesized by this method [7], 2 does not contain triethylamine ligand; but the infrared spectrum shows clearly the complexation of the lactone carbonyl to the metal: v(C==0)(l) = 1791 cm-1 and v(C=0)(2) = 1728 cm-1. The yellow complex 4a is obtained via the intermediate 3 (whose dimeric structure is based on its "P NMR spectrum, consistent with 31? NMR data available for the analogous binap complex [7]). 4a turns green on standing in degassed solvents, affording a mixture of two species 4a (63ip=54ppm) and 4b {6sip = 30 ppm), both soluble in cyclohexane (72% yield). No crystalli- zation of these complexes has been possible, but 4a can be isolated by selective quick solubilization in pentane. Although most of the phosphine- Ru" complexes are yellow [6-8, lOa], some green ones have been reported [11]; in particular, the dinuclear carboxylate complexes Rua(OAc)4 and Rua(OAc)4-2PPh3 are green [12], as well as the diop Ru" complexes Ru2Cl4(diop)3 and RuCl2(diop)(diop*), where diop* refers to a monodentate diop ligand [13]. The green solid 4 melts (m.p. = 134-137 C), while its color turns back to yellow, ruling out any usually green Ru"1 species [10b]. Since 4 149 Scheme 2. has provided a satisfactory elemental analysis, it is interpreted as a mixture of a monomer 4a and an oligomer 4b of a Ru11 complex interconverting in solution or by melting. Hydrogen transfer catalysis by 2 and 4 The reaction depicted in Scheme 2 has been studied. The catalytic species is prepared by mixing the complex 2 or 4 with 10 equivalents of sodium methylate in 2-propanol for 45min at 80 C. Upon addition of acetophenone with a 0.8% catalytic ratio, 4 gives 95% conversion and 5% e.e. in (+)-alcohol: this value lies in the same range as the e.e.'s obtained by ruthenium-diop-catalyzed hydrogenation [14], or by rhodium-diop- catalyzed hydrogen transfer [2b] (by contrast, rhodium-diop-catalyzed hydrogenation of acetophenone has been recently improved, providing much higher e.e.s [15]). In the same conditions, 2 gives 71% conversion and 2% e.e. in (+)-alcohol. Influence of temperature on catalysis by 4 Chemical and optical yields are improved by the choice of an optimal reaction temperature (the activation temperature and the activation time being respectively 80 C and 45min) (Table 1). The initial rate being five times higher at 60 C than at 80 C, we may suppose an additional activation step (enhanced at low temperature) by the acetophenone itself. The complex solution is stable under argon, but the optical yield is not improved on performing the reaction at room temperature for several days. We should emphasize the following points: a temperature over 70 C is needed for good catalytic activity; an activation time at 70-80 C for more than 45 min is needed for better enantioselectivity; too long an activation period tends to lower both the catalytic activity and the enantioselectivity in (-)-alcohol; NaOH/asbestos _, a change in the ratio from 2500 gmol to 1250 or [Ru] 12500 gmol"1 leads to a tremendous decrease of both the catalytic activity and the enantioselectivity in (-)-alcohol. Attempts at nitration before addition of acetophenone failed: the suspension is very fine (colloidal) and no separation is achieved; the same results are obtained from the filter and the unfiltered solutions. On the other hand, poor yields are provided in the absence of ruthenium. However, no inversion occurs, and the (+)-alcohol is still predominantly produced. Nature of the asbestos-modified asymmetric catalysts Whereas modification of homogeneous asymmetric catalysts by clay minerals has been widely studied [16], to our knowledge no attention has been paid to analogous modifications by asbestos. However, clay minerals, cationic zeolites [17] and asbestos [18] were used as supports in various transition metal-catalyzed reductions. Rhodium acetate Rh2(OAc)4 with triphenylphosphine has been reported as a good precursor to prepare a hydrogenation catalyst supported by hectorite [19]; this could be related to the specific influence of asbestos on the catalysis by the acetate complexes 4 and 5. Nevertheless, although clay minerals and asbestos exhibit analogous composition, their structures differ: clay minerals are lamellar aluminum silicates, and asbestos is mainly a fibrous magnesium and calcium silicate [20]. According to present knowledge about clay mineral organometallic interactions, we may assume that the Ru" complex [Ru]i loses the remaining acetate ligand, and displaces bivalent cations (Ca2"*", Mg2"1') at the edges of asbestos fibres. The resulting [Rulg and [Ru]s species are active catalysts, and hence still contain isopropoxide ligands; their basic structure could be: [asbestos ~Si 0 ]Ru(diop)(OiPr). A deeper penetration of ruthenium in the asbestos fibre could lead finally to the inactive species [Ru]4, without isopropoxide ligand. A likely structure for [Ru]4 could be: [asbestos ~ Si 0 ]zRu(diop). On the other hand, asbestos is well known to interact with organic molecules; therefore interaction of the reacting acetophenone with the surrounding asbestos is likely. Hydrogen transfer procedure 0.04 mmol of ruthenium (in complex 2 or 4) and 0.4 mmol of base or 100 mg of NaOH/asbestos (art. Merck 1564), were dissolved in 10ml 2-propanol. After the activation period, another 10ml 2-propanol and 0.50 ml (4.3 mmol) of acetophenone were added. The reaction was monitored by GC. After filtration over Celite, the alcohol was distilled; the e.e. was calculated from its optical rotation in methanol. Conclusion The chiral complexes 2, 4 and 5 are examples of both asymmetric hydrogen transfer ruthenium catalysts, and asbestos-modifiable asymmetric catalysts. Although no satisfactory optical yield enhancement of hydrogen transfer catalysis by phosphine rhodium complexes (without acetate ligand) has been yet achieved, the scope of asbestos-modified asymmetric catalysis deserves to be examined further. coredata.dc:description: The preparation of new chiral ruthenium complexes of (+)-diphenyl-phosphinite-pantolactone and (+)-diop is reported. Their catalytic properties in asymmetric hydrogen transfer from 2-propanol to acetophenone are investigated. In the framework of this reaction, the ability of asbestos to influence the kinetics, yield and enantioselectivity of asymmetric catalysis is evidenced. Using the complex [Ru(OAc)2((+)-diop)]n the overall optical yield changes from 12% in (+)-alcohol in the absence of asbestos, to 19% in (−)-alcohol in the presence of asbestos. Kinetic studies emphasize the determining influence of the activation conditions, the one-electron ligand of the ruthenium complex, and the ratio g[asbestos]/mol [Ru].
coredata.dc:title: Chiral ruthenium catalysts for asymmetric hydrogen transfer reduction of acetophenone: original effect of asbestos on enantioselectivity
